questions.question: Explain in one to two lines each of the 4 key elements that must be considered at the start of the project: Justification, Completion criteria, Deliverables and Success criteria. (JCDS)
questions.correctAnswer: Justification: Why should we do this project? What will we gain? Completion criteria: What will signal the end of the project? Project deliverables: What components will be delivered to the customer? Success criteria: What quantifiable criteria will determine whether a project was successful after its completion?

questions.question: Define constraint, what is TSB balance and why it's important?
questions.correctAnswer: Constraint: Something that could limit the progress or even the start of a project. The three main constraints are Time, Scope, and Budget. TSB Balance: If you're limited in one, the other two must give way or must be enhanced to account for the limitation. It's important because you can't have them all, so you must balance.

questions.question: Explain the cone of uncertainty?
questions.correctAnswer: Uncertainty in the schedule decreases as the project progresses

questions.question: What are the two extremes of planning and which extreme should we go for?
questions.correctAnswer: 1- Over Plan (traditional), 2- Don't Plan. The answer can vary between students.

questions.question: Explain the following elements of good planning: Reduces Risk, Reduce Uncertainty, Supports better decision making, Establishes trust and convey information. (RUDTI)
questions.correctAnswer: Reduces risk: Planning exposes potential dark corners of a project. Reduces uncertainty: We need to factor new knowledge we gain into the planning. Supports better decision making: Plans help us make decisions. Establishes trust: Reliable estimates build trust between the developer and customer. Conveys information: A plan conveys a set of baseline expectations.

questions.question: What are the 4 factors make planning agile? (FECS)
questions.correctAnswer: - Is more focused on planning than the plan. - Encourages changes. - Results in plans that are easily changed. - Is spread throughout the project.

questions.question: What is the Parkinson's Law.?
questions.correctAnswer: Work expands to fill the time available for its completion.

questions.correctAnswer: - Work (the database and API) finish later than planned, which will ripple through the project. - Work remains in process longer (20 days vs. 10). - Plus, we still need to add overhead time.

questions.correctAnswer: A unit of measure for expressing the size of user story/feature.

questions.question: Explain how ideal time is different than elapsed time. Which one is measurement for agile projects.
questions.correctAnswer: - Ideal time: time that something takes when stripped of all peripheral activities. - Elapsed time: time that passes on a clock/calendar.

questions.question: List the five advantages for estimating size in story points. (BEMFI)

questions.question: List the two advantages for estimating the user story size in ideal days.
questions.correctAnswer: 1. Ideal days are easier to explain outside the team. 2. Ideal days are easier to estimate at first.

questions.question: Explain how ideal days are easier to estimate at first.
questions.correctAnswer: Compared to ideal days, estimating in story points can be difficult and strange at first, especially with no baseline of previously estimated stories to compare with.

questions.question: List down the three techniques for deriving estimate and define each technique.
questions.correctAnswer: Expert opinion: An expert is asked to estimate the user story based on their intuition and experience. Analogy: Estimators compares the story with other stories. Disaggregation: Break a large story you find difficult to estimate into smaller stories you can estimate.

questions.question: Explain what triangulation in analogy estimation is, give an example.
questions.correctAnswer: Compare the story with an assortment of stories that have already been estimated. Example: If thinking of estimating a story at 5 points, compare it to a story you estimated at 3 and one you estimated at 8.

questions.question: Write two reasons of what is the problem with disaggregation of a user story.
questions.correctAnswer: 1. Forgotten tasks. 2. Summing many small errors can result in a larger error.
